description: From Middle English clege, from Old Norse kleggi, possibly ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *glōgʰ-s (“point”); compare with Norwegian Nynorsk klegg, Ancient Greek γλωχίς (glōkhís, “barb”).

entries.meaning: (Scotland, England dialect) A blood-sucking fly of the family Tabanidae; a gadfly, a horsefly.
examples: Sir Christopher Pack did cleave like a clegg, and was very angry he could not be heard ad infinitum.
